{{distinguish|Tewa language (Papuan)|Tiwa language}} {{Infobox language |name=Tewa |nativename= |states=[[United States]] |region=[[New Mexico]] |ethnicity=[[Tewa people]] |speakers=1,600 |date=2007 |ref=<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/languages-atlas/en/atlasmap/language-id-1540.html|title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger|website=www.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> |familycolor=American |fam1=[[Tanoan languages|Tanoan]] |iso3=tew |glotto=tewa1261 |glottorefname=Tewa |lingua=64-CAB-a |notice=IPA }}
'''Tewa''' is a [[Tanoan language]] spoken by [[Pueblo people]], mostly in the [[Rio Grande]] valley in [[New Mexico]] north of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]], and in [[Arizona]]. It is also known as '''Tano,'''<ref name = "native-languages" >{{Cite web | title = Tewa (Tano) Language and the Tewa Indian Tribes (Nambe, Pojoaque, San Ildefonso, San Juan, Santa Clara, and Tesuque Pueblos) | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://www.native-languages.org/tewa.htm }}</ref> or (archaic) Tée-wah.
== Dialects and usage == The 1980 census counted 1,298 speakers, almost all of whom are bilingual in English. Each pueblo or reservation where it is spoken has a dialect:
* [[Nambe Pueblo]]: 50 speakers (1980); 34 speakers (2004)<ref>{{Cite web | title = University of New Mexico Rewards Red Lodge Graduate | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | date = 2004-06-21 | url = http://www.unm.edu/news/Releases/04-06-21redlodge.htm }}</ref> * [[Pojoaque Pueblo]]: 25 speakers (1980) * [[San Ildefonso Pueblo]] (''P'ohwhóge Owingeh''): 349 speakers * [[Ohkay Owingeh]]: 495 speakers (1980) * [[Santa Clara Pueblo]]: 207 speakers (1980) * [[Tesuque Pueblo]]: 172 speakers (1980)
Tewa is also spoken by the [[Arizona Tewa]] (Hopi-Tewa, Tano) who live at Hano on the [[Hopi]] Reservation in [[Arizona]].
As of 2012, Tewa is defined as "definitely endangered" in Arizona and "severely endangered" in New Mexico by UNESCO.<ref>{{Cite web | title = UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | url = http://www.unesco.org/culture/languages-atlas/index.php }}</ref>
In the names "Pojoaque" and "Tesuque", the element spelled "que" (pronounced something like {{IPA|[ɡe]}} in Tewa, or {{IPA|/ki/}} in English) is Tewa for "place".
Tewa can be written with the [[Latin script]]; this is occasionally used for such purposes as signs (''Be-pu-wa-ve'', "Welcome", or ''sen-ge-de-ho'',"Bye"). Because alphabet systems have been developed in the different pueblos, Tewa has a variety of orthographies rather than a single standardized alphabet.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Evan Ashworth | title = On Nanbé Tewa Language Ideologies | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://www.linguistics.ucsb.edu/research/Ashworth_vol18.pdf }}</ref> The written form of the language is not as ubiquitous as in languages such as [[Cherokee language|Cherokee]] or [[Navajo language|Navajo]], because some Tewa speakers feel that the language should be passed on through the [[oral tradition]].<ref name = "native-languages" /> The Tewa language was a spoken language through the 1960s; [[language documentation|digital language documentation]] efforts were underway as of 1995.<ref> {{Cite web | title = Saving the Tewa Stories: A Model for Preserving Native Languages | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://www.washington.edu/research/showcase/1995a.html }}</ref>
== Phonology ==
The phonemes of Rio Grande Tewa are as follows:<ref>Randall Hannaford Speirs, "Some Aspects of the Structure of Rio Grande Tewa". 1966. State University of New York at Buffalo PhD dissertation.</ref>
=== Consonants === {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" rowspan="2" | ! rowspan="2" |[[Bilabial consonant|Labial]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2" |[[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- !<small>nor.</small> !<small>lab.</small> |- align="center" ! rowspan="3" |[[Stop consonant|Plosive]] !<small>voiceless</small> |p |t |ts |tʃ |k |kʷ |ʔ |- align="center" !<small>ejective</small> |pʼ |tʼ |tsʼ |tʃʼ |kʼ |kʷʼ | |- align="center" !<small>voiced</small> |b |d | |dʒ |ɡ | | |- align="center" ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] !<small>voiceless</small> |f |θ |s |ʃ |x |xʷ |h |- align="center" !<small>voiced</small> |v | | | | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m |n | |ɲ | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Flap consonant|Tap/Flap]] | |ɾ | | | | | |- align="center" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | | |j | |w | |}
=== Vowels === {| class="wikitable" ! ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] |- align="center" ![[Close vowel|Close]] |i |u |- align="center" ![[Close-mid vowel|Close-mid]] |e |o |- align="center" ![[Open vowel|Open]] |æ |a |}
== Language revitalization == [[Esther Martinez]], who lived to be 94 years old, was nationally known for her commitment to preserving the Tewa language.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Yvonne Shinhoster Lamb | title = Esther Martinez, 94; Preserved Language | work = Washington Post | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | date = 2006-09-19 | url = http://www.ilinative.org/share/programDirectory/programDirectory.xml }}</ref> Her San Juan Pueblo Tewa Dictionary was published in 1982. The [[Esther Martinez Native American Languages Preservation Act]] is named for her, and as of Sept. 15, 2012, members of the New Mexico congressional delegation have introduced legislation to extend the program for another five years.<ref>{{Cite web |title = Local news in brief |work = The Santa Fe New Mexican |accessdate = 2012-09-27 |date = 2012-09-15 |url = http://www.santafenewmexican.com/localnews/091512LocalBriefs |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130105030309/http://www.santafenewmexican.com/localnews/091512LocalBriefs |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-01-05 }}</ref>
Tewa language programs are available for children in most of the Tewa-speaking pueblos.<ref name = "native-languages" /><ref>{{Cite web | title = Poeh Center | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://poehcenter.com/ }}</ref> The Santa Clara Pueblo Tewa Language Revitalization Program also sponsors cultural activities, such as visiting [[Crow Canyon Archaeological Center|Crow Canyon]].<ref>{{Cite journal | volume = 4 | issue = 9 | title = American Indian Student Education Project : Language preservation educators, students, and staff visit Crow Canyon | journal = Crow Canyon Archaeological Center | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | date = 2009-09-25 | url = http://www.imakenews.com/crowcanyon1/e_article001547186.cfm?x=b11,0,w }}</ref>
Children's stories in Tewa have been digitized by the University of New Mexico, and are available online.<ref>{{Cite web | title = American Indians in Children's Literature (AICL): Pueblo Stories--in Tewa--Digitized at the University of New Mexico | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://americanindiansinchildrensliterature.blogspot.com/2012/03/pueblo-stories-in-tewa-digitized-at.html }}</ref>
A 2012 documentary film, "The Young Ancestors", follows a group of teenagers from [[Santa Fe Preparatory School]] as they learn the Tewa language in a self-study program with the help of a mentor, seventh grade literature teacher Laura Kaye Eagles.
== References == {{Reflist}} * Harrington, John P. (1910). [https://books.google.com/books?id=pDZOAAAAYAAJ A brief description of the Tewa language]. ''American Anthropologist'', ''12'', 497-504. * Speirs, Randall. (1966). ''Some aspects of the structure of Rio Grande Tewa''. (Doctoral dissertation, SUNY Buffalo). * [[Esther Martinez|Martinez, Esther]]. (1982). San Juan Pueblo Tewa Dictionary. San Juan Pueblo Bilingual Program, San Juan Pueblo, New Mexico.

(2012) ''Winds from the North: Tewa Origins and Historical Anthropology''. {{ISBN|978-1-60781-172-5}}.

page.title: The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean

revision.text:
'''''The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean''''' is a 2010 book edited by Walton Look Lai and Tan Chee-Beng and published by [[Brill Publishers|Brill]].
The essays in the book were previously published as a portion of an issue of the ''[[Journal of Overseas Chinese]]'', a publication of the [[International Society for the Study of Chinese Overseas]] (ISSCO) of Singapore. Look Lai is a [[University of the West Indies]] (UWI) professor who specialized in studying the [[British Caribbean]] population of Chinese and Southeast Asians. Tan, a Hong Kong-based man who is the editor of the ''Journal of Overseas Chinese'', is a specialist in studying the Southeast Asian ethnic Chinese populations.<ref name=Tchenp372>Tchen, p. 372.</ref>
==Contents== Look Lai wrote the introduction.<ref name=Tchenp372/>
The remaining portion of the book has three parts, which together have eight chapters.<ref name=Martin>Martin, Dorothea A.L. ([[Appalachian State University]]). "[http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/rezensionen/id=17733 Chinese in Latin America]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6Qy5kBCNG Archive]) H-Soz-u-Kult ([http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/index.asp?pn=about website of the History Department of the] [[Humboldt University of Berlin]]). 13 December 2013.</ref> The Chinese immigration discussed in these chapters include those from the early colonial era to the present.<ref name=Tchenp372/>
The sole article of Part I is "The Early Colonial Period" by Edward Slack, Jr. This article discusses the first [[Chinese immigration to Mexico]].<ref name=Martin/> The source material of this chapter originates from the [[General Archive of the Indies]] in [[Seville]], [[Spain]] and the ''[[Archivo General de la Nación (Mexico)|Archivo General de la Nación]]'' in [[Mexico City]].<ref>Tchen, p. 372-373.</ref> John Kuo Wei Tchen of [[New York University]] wrote that the Slack article "is a valuable baseline framing of the early Manila-Acapulco “China trade,” the Asian peoples moving to colonial Mexico, and the emergence of the New World typology of “chino” or “indio chino,” a legal subcategory of the “indios” of the Americas."<ref name=Tchenp372/>
Part II, "The Classic Migration," includes Chapters 2-5. Chapter 2, written by Look Lai, discusses overall migration from Asia during the 19th Century. Chapter 3, written by [[Evelyn Hu-Dehart]], discusses [[anti-Chinese sentiment]] in Latin America.<ref name=Martin/> Hu-Dehart's essay examines a question asked by [[Nicolás Cárdenas García]], a scholar from Mexico, on whether the Chinese in Latin America are "integrated and foreign."<ref name=Tchen373>Tchen, p. 373.</ref> Chapter 4,<ref name=Martin/> written by [[Belize|Belizian]] St. John Robinson, is a comparative analysis<ref name=Tchen373/> which discusses Chinese populations of Central America. Chapter 5, written by Lisa Yun, is an interview with [[Ruthanne Lum]] discussing Lum's book, ''[[God of Luck]]''. Dorothea A. L. Martin of [[Appalachian State University]] stated that the first two chapters of this section are "the anchors of the work".<ref name=Martin/>
Part III, "Old Migrants, new Immigration," includes Chapters 6-8. The overall focus are relations between different generations of immigrants in Latin America. Chapter 6, by Isabelle Lausent-Herrera, discusses the history and internal relations of [[Chinese Peruvians]]. Chapter 7,<ref name=Martin/> written by anthropologist Paul B. Tjon Sie Fat, discusses the groups of [[Chinese Surinamese]] and their responses to anti-Chinese sentiment.<ref name=Tchen373/> Chapter 8, by Kathleen Lopez, discusses [[Chinese Cubans]] in the post-Soviet Union era.<ref name=Martin/> The article discusses a [[China-Cuba relations|PRC-Cuba]] initiative to renovate the [[Havana#Chinatown|Havana Chinatown]].<ref name=Tchen373/>
==References== * Tchen, John Kuo Wei ([[New York University]]). "[http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/13822373-90002420 The Chinese in Latin America and the Caribbean]."(Book review) ([https://www.webcitation.org/6Qy6AecxI Archive]). ''[[New West Indian Guide]]'', Winter, 2012, Vol.86(3-4), p. 371(4) [Peer Reviewed Journal] {{ISSN|1382-2373}} - Cengage Learning
==Notes== {{reflist}}

{{dablink|This article is about the Japanese painting style. For the place in Tokyo, see [[Yōga, Tokyo]]. The Hindu philosophy is [[yoga]].}} {{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Kuroda-seiki-kohan00-6-1b.jpeg|thumb|''Lake Shore'' (湖畔), by [[Kuroda Seiki]] (1897)]] [[File:Reminiscence of the Tempyo Era by Fujishima Takeji.jpg|thumb|''Reminiscence of the Tempyo Era'' (天平の面影), by [[Fujishima Takeji]] (1902)]]
{{nihongo|'''''Yōga'''''|洋画||literally "Western-style painting"}} is a style of [[painting]]s by Japanese artists, made in accordance with Western (European) traditional conventions, techniques and materials. The term was coined in the [[Meiji period]], to distinguish such works from indigenous traditional [[Japanese painting]]s, or {{nihongo|''[[Nihonga]]''|日本画}}.
== History == European painting was introduced to Japan during the late [[Muromachi period]] along with [[Christian missionaries]]. Early religious works by Japanese artists in imitation of works brought by the missionaries can be considered some of the earliest forms of ''Yōga''. However, the [[sakoku|policy of national seclusion]] introduced by the [[Tokugawa bakufu]] in the [[Edo period]] effectively ended the influence of western art on Japanese painting, with the exception of the use of [[perspective (graphical)|perspective]], which was discovered by Japanese artists in sketches found in European medical and scientific texts imported from the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] via [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]].
In 1855, the Tokugawa ''bakufu'' established the ''[[Bansho Shirabesho]],'' a translation and research institute for western studies, including a section to investigate western art. This section was headed by [[Kawakami Togai]], whose assistant [[Takahashi Yuichi]] was a student of English artist [[Charles Wirgman]]. Takahashi is regarded by many as the first true Yōga painter.
In 1876, the ''Kobu Bijutsu Gakko'' ([[Tokyo Institute of Technology|Technical Art School]]) was established by the Meiji government as Japan's first dedicated ''Yōga'' art school. [[o-yatoi gaikokujin|Foreign advisors]], such as the Italian artist [[Antonio Fontanesi]], were hired by the government to teach Japanese artists, such as [[Asai Chu]] in the latest western techniques.
In the 1880s, the general reaction against Westernization and the growth in popularity and strength of the ''[[Nihonga]]'' movement caused the temporary decline of ''Yōga''. The ''Kobu Bijutsu Gakko'' was forced to close in 1883, and when the ''Tokyo Bijutsu Gakko'' (the forerunner of the [[Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music]]) was established in 1887, only ''Nihonga'' subjects were taught.
However, in 1889, the ''Meiji Bijutsukai'' (Meiji Fine Arts Society) was established by ''Yōga'' artists, and in 1893, the return of [[Kuroda Seiki]] from his studies in Europe gave fresh impetus to the ''Yōga'' genre. From 1896, a Yōga department was added to the curriculum of the ''Tokyo Bijutsu Gakko'', and from that point onwards, ''Yōga'' has been an accepted component of Japanese painting.
Since that time, ''Yōga'' and ''Nihonga'' have been the two main divisions of modern Japanese painting. This division is reflected in education, the mounting of exhibitions, and the identification of artists. However, in many cases ''Nihonga'' artists also adopted realistic Western painting techniques, such as perspective and shading. Because of this tendency to synthesize, although ''Nihonga'' forms a distinct category within the Japanese annual ''[[Japan Art Academy|Nitten]]'' exhibitions, in recent years, it has become increasingly difficult to draw a distinct separation in either techniques or materials between ''Nihonga'' and ''Yōga''.
== Materials == ''Yōga'' in its broadest sense encompasses [[oil painting]], [[watercolor]]s, [[pastels]], [[pen-and-ink drawing|ink sketches]], [[lithography]], [[etching]] and other techniques developed in western culture. However, in a more limited sense, ''Yōga'' is sometimes used specifically to refer to oil painting.

{{Taoism}} {{Distinguish|Zi Ran Men|Ziran the Tester}} {{about||the spice|cumin|the villages in Iran|Ziran, Iran|and|Ziran, South Khorasan}} {{Infobox Chinese |c=自然 |p=zìrán |w=tzu-jen |mi={{IPAc-cmn|zi|4|r|an|2}} |hangul=자연 |kanji=自然 |kana=じねん, しぜん |romaji=jinen, shizen |qn=tự nhiên }} '''Ziran''' is a key concept in [[Daoism]] that literally means "self so; so of its own; so of itself" and thus "naturally; natural; spontaneously; freely; in the course of events; of course; doubtlessly". <ref>Slingerland, Edward G. (2003). ''Effortless action: Wu-wei as conceptual metaphor and spiritual ideal in early China''. Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-513899-6}}, p. 97</ref><ref>Lai, Karyn. ''Learning from Chinese Philosophies: Ethics of Interdependent And Contextualised Self.'' Ashgate World Philosophies Series. {{ISBN|0-7546-3382-9}}. p. 96</ref> This Chinese word is a two-character [[compound (linguistics)|compound]] of ''zi'' (自) "nose; self; oneself; from; since" and ''ran'' (然) "right; correct; so; yes", which is used as a ''-ran'' [[suffix]] marking [[adjective]]s or [[adverb]]s (roughly corresponding to English ''-ly''). In Chinese culture, the nose (or zi) is a common metaphor for a person's point of view.<ref>Callahan, W. A. (1989). "A Linguistic Interpretation of Discourse and Perspective in Daoism", ''Philosophy East and West'' 39(2), 171-189.</ref>
==Origin== The word 'ziran' first occurs in the [[Daodejing]] (17, 23, 25, 51) and refers to the structure of [[Tao|Dao]], which cannot be referred back to anything else. It is generally accepted that the philosopher [[Laozi]], author of the Daodejing, coined the term. Ziran is a central concept of Daoism, closely tied to the practice of [[Wu wei|wuwei]], detached or effortless action. Ziran refers to a state of "as-it-isness,"<ref>Fu, C. W. (2000). "Lao Tzu's Conception of Tao", in B. Gupta & J. N. Mohanty (Eds.) ''Philosophical Questions East and West'' (pp. 46–62). Lanham: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers.</ref> the most important quality for anyone following Daoist beliefs. To become nearer to a state of ziran, one must become separate from unnatural influences and returned to an entirely natural, spontaneous state. Ziran is related to developing an "altered sense of human nature and of nature per se".<ref>Hall, David L. (1987). "On Seeking a Change of Environment: A Quasi-Taoist. Philosophy", ''Philosophy East and West'' 37(2), 160-171</ref> When it comes to sensibility of Taoism, the moral import can be most found in ziran.
==Recent reinterpretation== Ziran has been interpreted and reinterpreted in a great number of ways over time. Most commonly it has been seen as a model that was followed by the Dao, Heaven, Earth, and Man in turn, based on the traditional translation and interpretation of Chapter 25 of the Daodejing. Wang's more modern translation eliminates the logical flaw that arises when one considers that to model oneself after another entity may be to become less natural, to lose the 'as-it-isness' that ziran refers to. Wang reinterprets the words of Chapter 25 to be instructions to follow the model set by Earth's being Earth, by Heaven's being Heaven, and by the Dao being the Dao; each behaving perfectly in accordance with ziran. This interpretation reaffirms that the base nature of the Dao is one of complete naturalness.<ref name="Wang 2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.confuchina.com/05%20zongjiao/Lao%20Zi's%20Concept%20of%20Zi%20Ran.htm|title="It-self-so-ing" and "Other-ing" in Lao Zi's Concept of Zi Ran|last=Wang|first=Qingjie James|date=25 January 2003|accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
==Existence by Ziran== Wing-Chuek Chan provides another translation of 'ziran:' "It is so by virtue of its own".<ref name="Chan 2005">Chan, Wing-Chuek (2005). "On Heidegger's Interpretation of Aristotle: A Chinese Perspective", ''Journal of Chinese Philosophy'' 32(4), 539-557.</ref> This brings up ziran's link to another Daoist belief, specifically that the myriad things exist because of the qualities that they possess, not because they were created by any being to fulfill a purpose or goal. The only thing that a being must be when it exists in accordance with ziran is ultimately natural, unaffected by artificial influences.
==Additional information== Ziran and Tianran are related concepts. Tianran refers to a thing created by heaven that is ultimately untouched by human influence, a thing fully characterized by ziran. The two terms are sometimes interchangeably used.<ref name="Chan 2005" /> It can be said that by gaining ziran, a person grows nearer to a state of tianran.
Ziran can also be looked at from under Buddha's influence, "non-substantial". It is then believed to mean 'having no nature of its own'.<ref>Pregadio, Fabrizio. ed. (2008). ''The Encyclopedia of Taoism'' M-Z Vol 2. Routledge. pg. 1302</ref> In this aspect it is seen as a synonym of real emptiness.
D. T. Suzuki, in a brief article penned in 1959, makes the suggestion of ''ziran'' as an aesthetic of action: "Living is an act of creativity demonstrating itself. Creativity is objectively seen as necessity, but from the inner point of view of Emptiness it is 'just-so-ness,' (ziran). It literally means 'byitself-so-ness,' implying more inner meaning than 'spontaneity' or 'naturalness'".<ref>Suzuki, D. T. (1959). "Basic Thoughts Underlying Eastern Ethical and Social Practice." ''Philosophy East and West'' 9(1/2) Preliminary Report on the Third East-West Philosophers' Conference. (April-July, 1959)</ref>
==See also== * [[Pu (Daoism)]], a metaphor for naturalness * [[Tathātā]] or "suchness" in Mahayana Buddhism * [[Sahaja]], "coemergent; spontaneously or naturally born together" in Indian and Tibetan Buddhism
